awd_titl_txt: Extreme Weather Events in Mid-latitudes: The Role of Arctic Sea Ice, SST due to AMV and Siberian Snow Cover Through Teleconnections Involving the Stratosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
The project addresses the predictability of the wintertime climate over continental mid-latitude regions, with a focus on extreme events such as cold spells and extreme snowfall. Episodes of anomalously cold temperature and heavy snowfall have profound socio-economic impacts and can cause loss of life (for example, the cold winter in 2009/10 over the eastern US/Europe; deadly cold spell of February 2012 over central Europe; frigid temperature in March 2013 over the UK; cold snap of early January 2014 over the eastern US).  Various sources of predictability related to slowly evolving surface boundary conditions of the atmosphere have been identified in previous research.  In many instances, the increased predictability is related to atmospheric connections through wave propagation between widely different geographic regions, the so-called teleconnections.  Changes in surface heat flux due to the slow evolution of lower boundary conditions, such as sea-ice concentration change, sea surface temperature change or snow cover change may all drive teleconnections in the atmosphere. 

The resulting teleconnections can help foretell the mean climate as well as the occurrence of extreme events at seasonal to multidecadal time scales even in far away regions. The stratosphere is also a source of predictability, especially at the intraseasonal time scale since stratospheric anomalies (sometimes originating in the troposphere) propagate down into the troposphere several weeks later. The increasing availability of observations and progress in climate modeling have helped to better understand the role of surface and stratospheric conditions in driving the wintertime atmospheric circulation. However, fundamental aspects of boundary-driven teleconnections are still uncertain, due to the low amplitude of the forced signal compared to the unforced signal in the atmosphere in the observations and conflicting results in modeling experiments that use different models and/or slightly different boundary conditions. Some of the teleconnections are non-stationary in time as they are observed in certain time periods then disappear for reasons that are still unknown. Destructive interference between different teleconnections can explain the non-stationarity, but to date work has not been focused on understanding the combined (rather than individual) influence of surface anomalies. Moreover, the potential role of the stratosphere in modulating these teleconnections is poorly understood. These questions are at the core of the present project. It will examine the effects of different types of surface anomalies (Arctic sea ice, North Atlantic sea surface temperature, Siberian snow cover) that have been suggested as a source of predictability for the wintertime North American and Eurasian circulation. Using observations, global and simplified climate models, the project will explore how each forcing - as well as together - they may lead to a different frequency and/or intensity of cold spells in winter over continental mid-latitude regions. A particular focus of the project will be to examine the possible role of the stratosphere in facilitating connections between widely different geographical regions. 

Quantifying the likelihood of a change in the number and severity of extreme weather events based on the slower processes has important socioeconomic benefits.   Two graduate students will be educated and trained. Minority undergraduate students will continue to be involved in the research group.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored climate teleconnections due to anomalies in surface properties that influence the occurrence of winter extreme weather events in the densely populated regions of the Northern Hemispheric mid-latitudes, and the potential role of the stratospheric circulation in these teleconnections.

 

A major objective of this project was to explore the large-scale consequences of sea-ice decline in the Arctic, in particular, its potential impact on the mid-latitude climate. To that goal, and in addition to sea-ice-loss experiments of our own design, we have actively contributed to the Polar Amplification Multimodel Intercomparison Project (PAMIP). Several novel findings on that topic emerged from our research.

 

The impact of +2C Arctic sea-ice loss has a small signal-to-noise ratio, i.e., it is of small amplitude compared to internal variability (or chaos) in the atmosphere. This is apparent in our own simulations, but also in other experiments from the PAMIP effort. More specifically, we find that even in large ensemble of simulations (100 ensemble members of one year each), the climate noise due to polar-stratospheric variability, or internal oceanic variability in a coupled ocean model, still significantly affects the results. To make progress, we propose a new method to better assess the robustness of the response in 100-member ensemble of simulations. We also found that the Quasi-Biennial Oscillation (QBO) is an active player in the atmospheric teleconnections related to Arctic sea ice loss (and Eurasian snow-cover loss). We exposed the fact that the QBO must be considered when studying the large-scale atmospheric response to sea-ice anomalies, as it can be an additional source of spread in climate simulations and multimodel comparisons. The reason is that the QBO modulates the polar stratosphere in winter (the so-called Holton-Tan effect), a process that we have also investigated in detail, using a very large ensemble (1500-yr) of runs from a high-top climate model. For the first time, we detail longitudinal asymmetries in how the QBO impacts the extratropics, with the East Asia/North Pacific sector being key in the teleconnections. Such analysis helps to improve our understanding of the Holton-Tan effect and to evaluate the QBO in models.

 

Usually, sea-ice loss has been examined in atmospheric global climate models in terms of loss of sea-ice extent only, or decreased sea-ice concentration, without considering sea-ice thickness. In model experiments where we compare the effect on the atmospheric circulation of projected end-of century sea-ice thickness loss to the effect of projected sea-ice concentration loss, we find that the thickness loss reinforces the response to concentration loss, resulting in more robust response to sea-ice loss, especially in the high Arctic. However, we find that the Warm Arctic Cold Siberia (WACS) pattern, the most direct indication of extreme cold conditions in midlatitude Eurasia and the pattern most frequently attributed to sea ice loss, is weakly linked to sea-ice anomalies in the Arctic. To assess the impact of sea-ice loss alone to the combination of processes leading to Arctic warming, we compared atmospheric model experiments forced with projected sea-ice anomalies to nudging simulations that impose the entire projected column warming in the Arctic. Our results show that the large-scale response (WACS pattern) is sensitive to the vertical extent of the warming, such that the deeper the warming, the more pronounced the Siberian cooling. The sea-ice forced experiments only result in shallow warming in the Arctic, leading us to conclude that other processes (than sea-ice loss alone) of Arctic warming are important for affecting the mid-latitude climate.

 

Additional studies aimed to put the influence of Arctic warming in perspective with the more general influence of climate change in the mid-latitudes. In particular, we examined the tug-of-war effect, associated with warming of the upper tropospheric tropics, which in isolation would push the jet poleward, and the low-level Arctic warming in winter, on the midlatitude jet. Our nudging experiments revealed that the stratosphere is important in mediating the tug-of-war, such that after the stratospheric polar vortex gets established, the polar stratosphere response to tropical warming reinforces the effect of Arctic warming (no tug-of-war anymore), resulting in an equatorward shifted jet. In contrast, we found that when both effects compete, the jet narrows and strengthens in climate projections of the late 21st century. Once again, our work showed that the stratosphere is important for large-scale climate teleconnections.  Including stratospheric processes is essential to anticipate how the mid-latitude climate will change in the future.

 

We have identified the Ural-blocking pattern in fall as a robust precursor of polar-stratospheric and North-Atlantic-Oscillation variability in winter. The linkage is demonstrated by directly imposing the Ural-blocking pattern in the climate model through nudging in November, and examining how the circulation responds to that forcing in the following winter. Since Ural-blocking is an internal mode of variability that also forces Arctic sea-ice anomalies, this is critical to Arctic-midlatitude linkages, to attribute causality in ice-atmosphere interactions.
